utterances.speaker: JEANINE PIRRO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Judge Jeanine Pirro along with Jessica Tarlov, Lawrence Jones, Katie Pavlich, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is The Five.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.utterance: So, I'm not -- I have absolutely no intention of the Democrats not winning the House in November. I think that in terms of our work that this president has done has been a great president. I don't know about polls, but I do know about winning the races one district at a time.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: An utterly delusional Nancy Pelosi says everything is awesome in Joe Biden's America and that Democrats deserve to be rewarded in the midterms. Meanwhile, back in the real world, the president is setting records again for all the wrong reasons. Biden's approval hitting a record low in the new A.P. poll. Just 39 percent of the country thinks he's doing a good job. But record inflation is crushing Americans' wallets and surging gas prices setting a record for 11 days in a row and are now projected to go up to $6 this summer. But the Biden administration does not want to talk about it.

utterances.speaker: SEN. JOHN BARRASSO (R-WY)
utterances.utterance: Do you believe that gas prices are too high?

utterances.speaker: DEB HAALAND, U.S. INTERIOR SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: Completely understand the crunch that so many Americans are under right now. I think that there -- that Americans are still recovering from this terrible pandemic and there are a lot of other world events that are making things difficult for all of us.

utterances.speaker: BARRASSO
utterances.utterance: So, it sounds like you are unwilling to say that gas prices are too high.

utterances.speaker: HAALAND
utterances.utterance: We are doing all we can.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: And if you think they care about lowering the price of gas, Kamala Harris would rather boast about school busses going green.

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: Think about it. Yellow school busses are our nation's largest form of mass transit. How about that? Every day --

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: -- so, yes, and let's applaud, it gives them where they need to go. Now I've spoken to a number of drivers, for example, who have recently switched to electric busses and they stressed the importance of a quiet engine. It helps the drivers hear the road.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK, it's important to hear the road when you are driving a school bus. But you know what, I want to start with you, Katie. When Nancy Pelosi says I have absolutely no intention of losing the midterms this year, does she know something that we don't?

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: It's almost like they know they are so screwed that they are not just trying anymore, and they are just going to throw up their hands and say, of course, and be in denial, because there's nothing else, they can do to turn the ship around at this point. They're focused on all the wrong issues, but they want to talk about things that Americans aren't even, you know, thinking about at their dinner tables when they are looking at their budgets and so maybe she knows something that we don't. But the fact that all these Democrats are retiring from Congress, the fact that Republicans have generic ballot numbers we haven't seen in decades and Democrats are losing the very demographics, they would say, like Hispanics in Texas, for example, they are leaving the party in droves. So not only are they wrong on the issues, but their party is bleeding voters as well.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You know, it's interesting, Jessica, that Kamala is touting those green school busses, she finally found something to talk about.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: That is unkind, judge.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: is it? I think it's unkind to be the border czar or secretary or in charge of the border and not come up with any ideas other than, you know, I haven't been to Europe either.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: True. The school busses, I think it's important to have green school busses, I think bus drivers are incredibly important and they keep our kids safe and you don't want them hitting a little kid crossing the street. Obviously, it's not what everyone is talking about at the kitchen tables. They are talking about inflation, they are talking about the cost of food, their wages, all those kinds of things. Nancy Pelosi is the leader of the party in the House, she's not going to come out there and say you know, we are hoping for 30 lost seats and not 60, that when Republicans lose in a wave, they don't come out there and say that as well. But switching what you are talking about is something obviously people should start doing and if we look at the results from Tuesday, there were some progressives who didn't win their seats, but generally speaking moderate Democrats really the ones who prevailed. And you even saw in Pennsylvania with the biggest kind of upset for the progressive wing against the establishment, John Fetterman had actually pivoted his campaign halfway through to stop talking as much like Bernie Sanders and to talk a little bit more like Conor Lamb and then lo and behold he wins every single county in Pennsylvania. Katie mentioned the Hispanic vote. It's not just Texas. This was so jarring out of the A.P. poll that Biden is less popular among Hispanics than any other demographic. So, the only two groups where Biden is over water, over the 50 percent mark in terms of approval are with black voters at 65 percent and white college educated women, which I think is about 58 percent. You cannot win an election with just those two groups. And when you look at the enthusiasm gap and Karl Rove was on with Jesse last night talking about this and he had his whiteboard, and you could see the differences the uptick in Republicans coming out, and this happens in the first midterm of a presidency, it's undoubtedly concerning.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK, you know, Lawrence, as the gas prices go up and I understand that the state of Washington is anticipating that gas is going to go up to $10 a gallon, yes, that's what they actually said, that you know, the Democrats refuse to accept any responsibility, you know, when it's -- it's not just the energy secretary who says, but I had a magic wand, but it's the interior secretary we just heard from that you just saw. They are -- they are happy to not do anything and just kind of say it's Putin's fault when America doesn't believe it's Putin's fault. They could change the numbers if they wanted to.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. You know, judge, the issue, I was just in West Virginia and Pennsylvania. One lady told me that she is deciding between, if she was going to fill in -- fill up her gas tank or is she going to pay a bill. That's a big problem for voters there.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And it doesn't matter if I go to Atlanta or Philly or West Virginia, it's the same story. But the Democrats were in a pickle from the very beginning. If you are going to run for office, you need a great story to tell. Obama was hope and change, Trump was - make America great again but it was the forgotten men and women. Joe Biden was - restore the heart of America. He didn't have to focus on the issues that much because 56 percent of Americans, according to Gallup said they were better off under Trump than they would be under Biden. So, there wasn't really much that he could say was going bad for the country, but the tone of the country, I mean, when you got Donald Trump that's going in there fixing all the stuff, he came in with a wrecking ball, he didn't create a lot of friends in Washington. Here's going to be the problem for Joe going in the problem. You have the luxury to think about tone when everything is going well financially for you. But when mamas can't get stuff at the store for their babies, when gas prices are going up, when the border is out of control, when people don't feel safe in their communities, I mean, I guess he could run on promises made, promises kept. I mean, he did restore the soul of the country, but what do we get in exchange? We got a hot ass mess.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, we did, I think, you know, Joe Biden promised that he would be the adult in the room, and he would bring us together, and I think it was Joe Manchin who said my frustration is at an all-time high and he slammed Biden and the interior secretary Haaland, H-a-a-l-a-n-d, for doing nothing to alleviate the pain that Americans are going through. It's the inability to emphasize that I think the Democrats have a real problem with.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: And you know, that I am really good at empathy.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The best.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am a hot ass empathizer, Lawrence. Someone should tell Nancy that you can't preserve political power like with a shot of Botox. It's not a frown line, it's a gas line. She doesn't know what she's doing. These problems are real, they are palpable. They're not some kind of abstract that you can deal with wokeism. And it's amazing how many of these problems have developed under Biden that were supposed to develop under Trump. Because Trump was inexperienced, right, he was a buffoon, perceived buffoon and then what happens, everything that was supposed to happen is now happening under Biden. It's like you were worrying about monkeypox and then you get hit by a truck and that truck happens to be Joe Biden. We always hear from addicts you have to hit rock bottom before you change, so what the hell is the rock bottom right now for Democrats. We are just watching the gas prices go up. Watching crime still spiral out of control, we're watching high illegal immigration. There's no solutions, right. They are not offering any solutions. So, we don't know what the new bottom is, we don't know what the new low is. We could have $20 gas if we don't think about it. The problem with Joe, and then I'll stop, is that it's a double-barreled problem. You have an empty vessel, which is Joe, who is in a natural state of decline, let's be honest, that's not to be mean, just observing what we see, but what it has raised to fill that void is wokeism. So, you have -- it's a compounded problem. So, you are basically fighting these problems in a hole because Biden wasn't surrounded by moderate voices. He's only been surrounded by wokesters who can't solve any problems. Hence, it's getting worse. And we will, I don't know what the bottom is anymore, I wish I did.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I wish we get to it so we can start to crawl out of this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: But this is a Fox News alert. We have a federal judge's decision on Title 42. The United States judge has just blocked Biden's plan to lift COVID border restrictions for migrants, keeping it in place. The Trump-era policy that let border patrol agents deport large groups of migrants quickly over safety concerns. That comes as border apprehensions hit a new record in April with 234,000 migrant encounters. OK, you can see it right up there, 2,034 -- 234,000. What do you say about this? I'll go -- I'll start with you, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, this is a good thing according to the Texas DPS and to border patrol and to folks down there who are trying to stem the flow, but this isn't going to cut down on the numbers of people as a result. So, this is something that was put into place during COVID to keep that issue at bay. But as we know already, the border patrol and ICE are already having to release a number of individuals already into the country depending on where you are from. And also, until the asylum rules are changed, and you can say something other than I'm afraid to go home, that's what gets you your ticket to any city in the country, really, if you are not a single adult male, the flow will continue. So, I think that law enforcement officers will be happy about this decision, but they will say that they still have major challenges. Because a lot of these numbers that you've seen, most all the numbers have been under Title 42 and it hasn't been a total deterrent.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: All right. Bill Melugin is live in Eagle Pass, Texas with the latest from the border.

utterances.speaker: BILL MELUGIN, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Judge, do you want like elements or you want me to just react to it or what?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Hi, Bill. You are on, Bill.

utterances.speaker: MELUGIN
utterances.utterance: Hey, guys, we're just getting that breaking news as you are right now, just hearing that the federal judge has blocked the administration's effort to drop this on Monday. Obviously, border patrol agents and Texas DPS, this is going to be welcome news to them, but really, all it's going to do is kick the can down the road. Title 42 is going to have to drop at some point in the future, but that's just not going to be on Monday. But even with Title 42 in place we've still seen an explosion in numbers. We just had more than two, you know, well over 230,000 migrant apprehensions this last year in April, the highest in DHS history. We had more than 200,000 the month before. We had more than 1.3 million illegal crossings since the start of the fiscal year on October 1st. So, even with Title 42 in place, we've seen an explosion of numbers. And what this means now, is for certain countries, for certain demographics, the U.S. government will still be able to expel them back to Mexico, meaning that you know, we have shown this video where once people come across and they are detained by border patrol, rather than having to take them into the processing center and do paperwork for hours, they're able to essentially just put them right back onto a bus, drop them off at the port of entry and expel them back into Mexico. The whole process can take less than an hour. They've used it more than 1.7 million times since March of 2020, that being both the Trump administration and the Biden administration. But I can tell you, front line border agents they will be happy to hear this news because I've been texting with them for the past several weeks, ever since news came down that they were planning to get rid of this on May 23 and they were basically saying buckle up, because it's going to be total anarchy and chaos down here at the border. DHS is on projections were saying upwards of 18,000 illegal crossings a day could have happened if Title 42 were to drop. You do the math on that, that's about 540,000 crossings in one single month, mMore than half a million. And just to put that in perspective that would be more than double what we just saw last month in April, which was the highest in U.S. history. So, probably a little bit of a sigh of relief for border agents and Texas law enforcement, but not too much because, again, these numbers have been exploding even with Title 42 in place. You don't have well over 200,000 apprehensions at the border month after month without there being a serious surge at the border and we've been showing the video all day long. We keep getting these massive groups of 150 to 200 crossing every single day. So, what does this mean big picture, it means that the administration cannot get rid of Title 42 on Monday as planned, they have to keep enforcing it while this litigation plays out. We'll send it back to you.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Bill, you know, when you say that 1.7 million since 2020 have been sent back because of Title 42, how do they make a decision that someone should be sent back based on Title 42? We weren't even COVID testing these people. So, how do they make that decision?

utterances.speaker: MELUGIN
utterances.utterance: Well, really it depends what country they're from and what their demographic is. So, it really started off with those Northern Triangle countries. It would be Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador. At that time, we had agreements with those countries that we would repatriate the migrants back to those countries. We would put them on flights or we would just kick them back to Mexico. We would do the same thing with Mexicans. Then along the way, you know, once the administration's changed, deals changed with countries in the Northern Triangle. Nicaraguans, for instance, they're, for the most part, just release once they're encountered by border patrol, because for the most part, they won't take their citizens back unless they have a passport. Cubans are mass released. We don't enforce Title 42 with them, and Venezuelans are released. We don't have a Title 42 agreement with them. And one of the criticisms has been that the Biden administration can just, you know, put them on a bus and send them back to Mexico. But for some of these demographics, they have preferred to put them on an airplane and send them back, you know, they're called repatriation flights.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Right. Right.

utterances.speaker: MELUGIN
utterances.utterance: And you know, yes, the border patrol union says if we really want to enforce Title 42 across the board, just kick everybody back to Mexico. The administration hasn't done that. They have preferred to try to fly some people back.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MELUGIN
utterances.utterance: And when those host countries --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I understand.

utterances.speaker: MELUGIN
utterances.utterance: -- don't cooperate they can't do it.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK. Thank you very much, Bill Melugin. You know, the question that I'm getting at, Lawrence, is the fact that the decision to send people back to the original country has nothing to do with 42. They are saying 42. But if Nicaragua won't take them back, then what does it do for 42 or not? So, it seems that 42 is being used in some cases but not others.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, I would say this, just based on the report and I've done it at the border, 42 has been used as a Band-Aid. It's not going to fix the big, the mass problem that's at the border.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: On another note, and the judge did the Biden administration a favor here right here. But number two, as a result of the judge making this decision, a lot of women and children are going to be placed in danger coming across the border. Because a lot of the folks keep asking well, why are they bringing the children across the border, because it's a ticket. I mean, they know that they can get across and that -- this is why you don't see a lot of people running away at the border. Most of the runners that you see are single adult males because they realize that they can't come into the country under Title 42. So, this is going to put our border patrol agents yet again in a bad position but again, it's going to put these kids and these women in a bad position as well. Joe Biden needs to understand this. This is going to be a terrible issue for those Democrats that are on the border areas. They are Democrats at heart. But what they are saying if they cannot do this, they understand the voters are putting a lot of pressure on them because of this issue. And I'll just note this, because I know Jess is going to hop in on this. These are Latinos too, as well. There are 50 percent, over 50 percent of the border patrol agents are minority. When you look at the Texas DPS that are doing a lot of the patrols, they are minorities.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: When you look at those districts that are at the border, they are minorities. This is not a matter of if you hate the people and you want then to get a better life, this is about law and order and the strain of resources in those areas.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You know, Jessica, the point that Lawrence makes is a good one, how is it going to affect those Democrats who are along the border who are running for office?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, I think it's a boon on the immigration issue for Democrats at these particular moments because it gives us a few more months to listen to Democrats like Ruben Gallego who most likely is going to challenge Kyrsten Sinema for her seat in 2024 in Arizona. And it feels like a ripe time to put together some sort of commission, like Will Hurd, I don't know what he's doing now that retired from Congress, he's a Republicans and like Gallego or someone else on border together for a bipartisan plan to do this. Because Title 42, it was a Band-Aid, and we had a very thoughtful conversation on the show yesterday about this issue where it was acknowledged that this is a health policy. Title 42 came into --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: -- being because of COVID. We are moving towards a world where hopefully COVID is not something that should be running our immigration policy, what is the next step. So hopefully now we have a few months, we have the summer, where there is going to be very high numbers of crossings to deal with that, and we can go into November with the clear plan.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK, wrap it up for us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, it is a testament to how appealing our systemically racist country is that millions of nonwhites want to come here. But the admin -- as long as we care about immigration, it's like crime and it's like inflation, the White House won't because in their view we only view these concerns because we are deplorables embracing, you know, replacement theory. When all it is, and all of these things whether it is crime or whether it's inflation or immigration, it's about process. It's about rules. It's not about people. We are a big -- Republicans and conservatives and libertarians, we are all about -- we're all about systems. We just want you to be part of the system and do it the right way. And so, what's happening now, you see a lot of people painting a broad brush of this racism stuff and this is -- and this is their way of doing it here like they did with crime and elsewhere.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Go ahead, Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. On the bigger issue of the systems, Bill reported earlier today that there is an American citizen who was arrested in Texas for helping to smuggle illegal immigrants across the border. Bigger picture, the longer this lawlessness goes on and the systems are disrespected, and border patrols mission is to process people, not to enforce the border and protect the country, that corruption will breed and it will get completely out of control. And it will reach public officials, law enforcement. So, there is a longer-term consequence to allowing this type of lawlessness to continue and once it's in those systems, we start looking a lot like the Mexican corruption and that's a lot of the reason why this is happening as well and once you get to that point, it's really difficult to go back.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: And the sad part about it is that with the administration flying people into the interior of the United States, that corruption is going to spread quicker than we can imagine. All right, we are going to keep an eye on this breaking news. A federal judge blocking President Biden's plan to end Title 42. More of The Five is next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Black Lives Matter getting called out for living large while the people they claim to be helping were being killed in the streets. The group using $90 million in donation money to purchase lavish mansions and enrich the friends and family of their co-founder. But that wealth didn't translate to saving the lives of black Americans. Instead, they bore the brunt of the surge in murders following the George Floyd riots of 2020. Take a look at this chart from the Manhattan Institute, the red line showing how the increase in violence disproportionately affected black victims. But of course, BLM co-founder Patricia -- Patrisse Cullors, excuse me, says she's the victim in all of this.

utterances.speaker: PATRISSE CULLORS, CO-FOUNDER, BLACK LIVES MATTER
utterances.utterance: Much of the funding that came in was from individual donors, that was a lot of white guilt money. Some of my mistakes are being weaponized against me and also the entire movement and that's truly disappointing to see us fall into that as well.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Lawrence, you are laughing at this one.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Such a joke, and they all got played and I'm enjoying every bit of this. You know, there was the woke tax and then there was the white guilt tax. The woke tax was for the corporations, I mean, I don't believe in any of this stuff. if you look at the corporations, they're not as woke as they pretend to be. They've been -- but they had to pay Black Lives Matter in order to not be boycotted or their buildings -- that was their protection, got to pay the king his tax. As for the individual donors, they must not have any black friends. I mean, because black people weren't supporting the organization Black Lives Matter. Black folks on the street were saying equal justice under the law. That's it. They never said support this organization. Many of the values that the organization represents are totally against how I was raised and most black people were raised in our community. So, we never supported the organization. We always thought the organization was a joke. We also didn't support defunding the police. If you look at Pew research, there are more white people that support defunding the police --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: -- than actual black people. So, the question is, who are these people listening to? Not black people.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, there are a lot of civil rights leaders too from 60s -- JONES; Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- who came out against Black Lives Matter early and of course their voices were not amplified by the media. Greg, I want to get your response to white guilt money. And white liberals sending all this money to BLM thinking they were doing something good and putting a yard sign up and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She's right, it is white guilt money, it's also like I'm thinking about it was all -- whenever I remember the BLM protests angry college chicks, and then I get to go to the suburbs and you see the list signs.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They are just like -- it's like what does all this is, is virtue - - like a massive delusional virtual signal. If I do this, I'm a really good person and it's almost as though BLM didn't exist for blacks, as you say, it existed for the white liberal to feel good about themselves, all those corporations had those earnest wokesters and human resources back in BLM. They, you know, we don't just make candy bars, we, you know, we encourage social change and you go home and you don't really care. None of the stuff that these activist supporters did help anybody, except in terms of statistic, criminality. I mean, it's kind of sad but BLM hurt more blacks than it helped.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When you look at those numbers, it's stunning.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Judge, what about the extortion BLM was engaged in, you know, demanding that corporations and individuals give money or, you know, the riots and violence is going to continue. I mean, that's what happened.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Well, here is the question. Do the corporations that gave the money consider themselves extorted? I mean, did they do it for virtue signaling as Greg just talked about, or do it because they felt they didn't want to be boycotted or, you know, like, you know, it's like the mob coming in and saying you know, you want protection money, give us -- you want protection, give us the money. But you know what, what's most interesting about this, is that the nation's political culture has played a role in the crime that occurred during the pandemic and right after George Floyd's murder because we know that in Democrat-leaning cities more African Americans were killed, victims of murder, than there were in white-leaning, you know, Republican cities. So, with the same time the crime is going up in the black communities you've this Patrisse Cullors, who is no better than a two-bit scammer that I prosecuted for years. Who is out there saying I want to take money for Black Lives Matter? You know, you people, whether she wants to call it white guilt doesn't matter, she used it to enriched herself, her baby daddy, her brother. She gave more than five times the money for the Trayvon Martin Foundation to her baby daddy, OK? And I think that these people have to be prosecuted. Forget about the corporations. You know what? They got suckered. They get suckered all the time, and I'm disgusted with them. But that's not the big issue. The big issue is that this woman is now complaining that it's been weaponized against her. You know what, let me show you the penal code. That's being weaponized. When they bring the justice system against you for the scamming the way they just did to an activist BLM leader in Boston who faces fraud charges for laundering 2020 donations for personally enriching themselves. This is where we need the hand of justice to come in and start prosecuting these people. It's not your piggy bank. And how dare you cause division because you just want to make money for yourself.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Jessica, and my colleague, Julio Rosas, who covered these riots extensively, wrote a book about what happened. And in the book, what's interesting is he talks about how the damage is not temporary. So, when the cameras leave and the rioters leave, these communities, these Black communities have been devastated for decades, and there's no one there. There's no economic influence to go in as a result of the damage that's been done. And so the question is, how did the same people who donated all this money to BLM, the white guilt money, now make up for the fact that they were supporting a movement that has destroyed entire communities for at least a generation?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: In defense of white guilt -- give me a second here. I don't think - -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And baby daddies.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: And baby daddies. I'm getting there too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a better name for pregnant -- than pregnant man is baby daddy.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I don't --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK. More on the white guilt.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: It isn't fair to me to tarnish a group of people who were genuinely horrified by what they saw. And this was across the board, right? Everyone unilaterally saw what happened to George Floyd.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Everyone.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Everyone.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Everyone.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: And that they did what they thought was right, which was there was a prominent organization that was saying that they were --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Prominent amongst who? White people.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, they have --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They weren't prominent.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Do you think if you are just an average person who's trying to put food on the table, and you saw the footage, the -- you know, the eight and three-quarters minutes of what happened to George Floyd and you see someone on the television who's saying, I've run an organization that is trying to fix this problem. There's systemic racism in this country and criminal justice reform issues needs to be pushed forward. And if you donate to me, I will help them. That it's their fault for not doing the research on who Patrisse Cullors actually is?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is. They got --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: It's not --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: First of all, that's not --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And it is such the typical white liberal response that if we just throw money on it, if we go -- instead of -- instead of --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: You can't. Everything can't be white liberals' fault. It's just not possible that everything is.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what? You know what? A lot of this stuff impacting Black America, and all the policies that you guys have implemented in our community are white liberals responsibility --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I am not --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Because we don't endorse them in our community. All I'm saying, it was lazy, it was petty. I was at the --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: But it wasn't malicious. That's my point. And can I just finish my point?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It wasn't malicious because, Jessica, I was at those rallies when it was all white people there. And when Black told them --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I was at the rallies too.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They told them to stop burning our places, and they continue to do it and weaponize the police against us. I was there every single one of them, and they did and continue to divide the country. So. again, it's their fault for being suckered.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I'm the first person to say that, you know, the fact that Latin X even exists as a term is a white person's problem. I mean, Latinos do not like that term. It's a similar thing that Black people were not supporting BLM. But they were supporting the movement. And I think that it's unfair to say that cities and communities in these small mom-and-pop shops have been decimated just because of that. We have an education problem. We have a media problem that people are not publicizing the stories necessarily from the beginning to say, this is who those people are. And also that people weren't thinking widely enough, because what the Black Lives Matter movement was actually about was systemic racism in all corners of the country, so people could donate to organization -- free speech organizations, climate organizations.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: No, it wasn't about systemic racism at all.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Of course, it was.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Because if you said white lives matter, you got canceled.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Because --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Don't talk to me about across-the-board systemic.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: The reason that white lives matter or all lives matter or blue lives matter was --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: First of all, whoever heard of them, this is not a long -- an organization, just in defense of Lawrence, that was around for 10 years of the charity --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: He defended himself just fine.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They got suckered. It's their fault.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I've been writing about Black Lives Matter since 2014 and exactly who they are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I actually founded it in the early '80s.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And I've been called -- I've been called a racist a lot. And now we know the truth about them. So, "THE FASTEST" is up next.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All right, so first up, liberal NPR reportedly has a system where people can secretly snitch on coworkers who aren't complying with their draconian mask-wearing policy. The company actually encourages others to correct their co-workers or rat them out to the higher-ups and repeat offenders could be fired. Greg, what do you think about this?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, the left always has an obsession with power and authority even though they condemn the right for the very same thing. But he might -- you want to talk about draconian? I mean, you think NPR is bad. There's a company that sends employees home for five days, even if they don't have COVID, and they'll make you wear a mask for 10 days even if you test negative for COVID. And these rules are purely arbitrary, but we -- but these employees have to do it. It's like a new lockdown. We're all either said oh, wait, it's our company. Yes. We are actually held captive by some anonymous legal executive that is like terrified of some like -- I don't know, is it -- is it New York? We have to stop this. We cannot be crapping on NPR or anybody else if we are equally as draconian. We are sending people home who are healthy. We have -- people are at home who are testing negative because somebody else tested positive. Nobody even has symptoms. This is -- this is madness and it has to stop.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I went home this week because I was sick but I didn't have COVID. So, what does that mean?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? We missed you. We missed you.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You did not miss me. You weren't even here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I sent you flowers.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You weren't even here. You didn't send me flowers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I sent you flowers.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You did not send me baby formula for my daughter's baby.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Y'all, y'all, y'all, I still need my job. So, Katie --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't care. I'd rather be sent home over talking the truth than a negative COVID test.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Katie?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I agree. OK --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Didn't you watch? You could be a carrier.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am a carrier of many things. Just see what's in my pocket.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Who's next? Call out me?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I guess we should just move on to the next topic.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think Greg said everything.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All right, so up next, a senior prank at Texas High School going haywire and causing thousands of dollars in damage and forcing the school to cancel classes for the remainder of the year. Video shows wipe off from fire extinguishers filling the vandalized cafeteria. The students responsible apparently are going to have to pay for the mess they created and may face criminal charges. Jessica, did you do this in high school?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I did not. But we had one of those senior pranks. And Chevy Chase went to my high school and he walked a cow up to the roof because you know they can't go backwards. This is totally real and very Chevy Chase.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's very good.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Katie, what happened was just skipping school?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Hey, I love the story because I helped plan my senior prank and it was flawless. And we had a whole game plan and whiteboards and maps and radios and we had outfits. We looked like ninjas. The key is, you don't cause damage. Like you do something very annoying, but you don't vandalize anything. So, we filled 10,000 Dixie cups up with a little bit of water and filled the whole school so they had to start school late. And then we zip-tied all the doors together.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: So, these were amateurs.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They're amateurs. They're not as organized as I was pulling up and didn't get caught.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Greg, do you have some --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Watching your prank was literally we prank seniors. Like, senior citizens.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Wait, actually? That's so mean.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We break into their home -- we break into their homes and we moved everything around. So, they wake up in the morning and they walk into furniture. It was a terrible thing. I just -- I think this is bad. I think that the school janitor gets to go to each student's house to do the same thing to their bedroom with a fire extinguisher because the seat -- you know, the janitor is going to have to deal with this stuff. So, they should do the same thing to the students' houses bedrooms, or maybe the whole house. That would be fun.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Judge? I skipped my senior year of high school.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Too smart for that scandal.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I was done.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You were done with it, you just left?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I went to college after junior year.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I'm not mad at you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did you go away and then return with a child? Remember that? They used to do that.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: They did.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I came back with a kid.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Hey, Judge, Judge, it's my time.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Oh yes. This is your time? OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And finally, age is just a number, right? Nearly half of Americans don't feel like they're an adult until they reach the age of 30. I'm 29, so I am not adult yet. Jessica?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Age shamer.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I stayed in school for a very long time. So, I agree with this. And I didn't think that big responsibility started until 30-plus.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Judge?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I think especially today, I don't think kids mature until their 30 today.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Katie, my bills say otherwise.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. I would say I definitely feel like an adult but also still figuring out. Like, this survey, I'm curious how old the people were, who took the survey? Because I feel like in every stage of life, you're like, am I doing this the right way? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Am I screwing it up? Am I doing a good job?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: What about a senior citizen like you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, I'll tell you one thing. And that's disgusting you would say that. We're going to HR. You're coming up with me.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Oh, boy. You're already on your way, brother.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. I used to think, this self-selects for weird people. Who fills out a survey from a mattress company? It's somebody with a lot of free time.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: They pay you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do they? How do you know that?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: How do you know that?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I work in polling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You did it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You work in polling? Can I get paid of something?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Have we met before?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I didn't know you work in polling.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All right, we got to go.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: "FAN MAIL FRIDAY" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The great thing about Friday is there's none of the executives really watch the show?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: They're walking to you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You think I'm OK?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: For 12 more minutes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: For 12 -- yes. The first question from Janet O. Oops, it stopped. What old person things do you do? First, this assumes that old people do specifically old things which I resent, Jessica. But what old person things do you do?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I don't want to offend anyone but these are two weird things or things that I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Older people do?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: -- older people do. Like, I save food in the refrigerator forever.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is, yes. My mom would do that.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Yes. And just keep going through it like an old -- I love like cold Chinese food.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I will just eat like a dumpling a day and my husband was like, you got to stop doing that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A dumpling a day.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It's disgusting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It sounds like a children's book, a dumpling a day.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: It's not too disgusting. Anyway, that was good enough. I'm not going with the second one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Lawrence?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I need to eat or I get very angry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, cranky. I'm a cranky, very cranky.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Oh, cranky.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cranky. I buy -- yes, I was old when I was born.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes. Same.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, cranky. I make a mess everywhere. That's what a lot of old people do.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Old people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Katie?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Puzzles.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right. That's good for your brain.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I feel that's also hipster.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Printing -- well, maybe. I'm printing things out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I don't have a printer.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Reading real books.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Buying real books.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I just think that's normal behavior, though.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Judge, what about you?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, I do two things that are kind of schizophrenic. I like -- what? Stop laughing, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Just two?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes. One is I save paper towels. I hate when people waste paper towels. They have nothing to do with the pandemic, OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's so funny.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I'm talking, OK. And the second thing I do that old people do is you figure you don't have much time left, so go out and buy jewelry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. You know, I do -- I save like, all the stuff I get from delivery. I have a big thing of like napkins and plastic forks like there's like a nuclear war is coming.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is coming.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: It is coming. Not a nuclear war, but --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Also, you know what I do that old people used to do in my neighborhood? I pay people to do chores. Like, you know, like, I keep --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: So do I.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You do?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Why is that an old person thing?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you're not doing it yourself?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: That's got nothing to do with old, honey. I was doing that when I was in my 20s.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nothing. We're going to move on. What's -- this is from Fred. What's the earliest news story from your childhood that impacted you? All right, Katie. And don't say --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The Bill Clinton scandal?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's good. That affected a lot -- infected a lot of people. It affected and infected. Sorry about that. That's very good.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The Clinton scandal. Also, I remember the first invasion of Iraq.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You were young.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It was.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are. How about you, Lawrence?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: 9/11, yes. How old were you?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Third grade.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Third grade. OK. Wow.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow, I was only --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: What did she say?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Nothing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What did she say? Thank you for the help, Judge. I didn't know she was here.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You were looking at me. I want to do --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: He was going in order.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was afraid you get violent if I'd let Jessica first.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I was going to say, the Clinton election, and then obviously the scandal was the big one. But that was the first like political story I was aware of was the election.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's see if judge picks the same one I pick.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I remember being in grammar school, and I think that Kennedy was shot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's a good -- yes.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: It's like, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's -- see, I was -- I went with Watergate.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I was in law school during Watergate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Nobody cares.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was at the Watergate Hotel.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You were?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK. Did you -- did you meet people there?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I actually put on a play. I put on a little puppet show based on Watergate in second-grade summer school. It's pretty weird.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I was a dork.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Who was the protagonist?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Spirit Wagon. "ONE MORE THING" is up next. I'm dead.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING" and I go first. Now, there's this -- OK, stop, Greg, stop. All right, St. Jude -- this is serious stuff. The St. Jude patient draws a monster truck and he gets surprised with a real life full-size version featuring his artwork. There's the real monster truck. His name is Calvin. He is a cancer patient when he drew his own version of Monster Jam toy truck. But what's significant about this folks is he added emojis to reflect his feelings throughout his 18 months of chemo and radiation.
